text: Radegunde was the eldest.
She had five younger siblings, a real rascal gang. The smallest of them, Luitgard, was less than a year old when her mother Richenza died. And it wasn't even born when Radegunde's cousins left.

Radegunde's mother had an older sister, Maximiliane, who lived in Frankfurt. Richenza and her family, on the other hand, lived in a village near Wiesbaden, the sisters' home town. Maximiliane had married from Wiesbaden to Frankfurt, and Richenza had been married from Wiesbaden. Maximiliane, the older one, had been supposed to travel from Frankfurt especially for her sister's wedding - but for reasons that Radegunde never wanted to be told about, she had missed the ceremony.

Frankfurt was not very far away, and as Richenza and Maximiliane were very attached to each other, they made sure to see each other at least once every six months. This meant that Richenza came to Frankfurt with her children, as her sister never left the city - also for reasons that were not explained to Radegunde. Due to all these circumstances, however, Radegunde knew her two cousins quite well. Maximiliane had two sons: Rudolph, the older one, who was over ten years older than Radegunde, and Max, the younger one, who was a little older than she was. There were no other children. There were strange rumors about Max, which had something to do with his mother's disappearance at her sister's wedding and the reason why Maximiliane Halbig no longer left her husband's town. Radegunde didn't know exactly what it was, but she knew that old Master Halbig didn't like his youngest son.

For them, it was almost part of the Halbig household. Every time they stayed in Frankfurt, there was trouble between Max and his father. Sometimes there was wild shouting and a chase across the yard, sometimes Max had a black eye when they arrived, sometimes he was locked in the cellar. Rudolph usually intervened before things got too bad. Radegunde was never quite sure what Max had done to provoke his father's blows and anger. She really liked her cousin's jokes and tricks, she liked his funny, mischievous manner and his cheeky remarks made her blush but also giggle. Max himself seemed to have come to terms with the fact that his father hated him. He adored Rudolph for that.

It was impossible not to like Rudolph. Not only was he kind and clever, he was also incredibly good-looking and made the girls sigh. He was affectionate towards Max, and just as affectionate towards Radegunde and her siblings. She could well understand that Max adored him. She basically did it to him herself.
And then the day came when the brothers left.

Richenza was terribly upset about this. Why should they both, she argued, shouldn't at least one of them stay with their mother? Should her sister lose both children in one fell swoop to such an uncertain adventure? Off to the Holy Land with King Konrad - good heavens! Who knew if the boys would ever come back from there!
But when Radegunde asked her mother which of them should stay at home, she fell silent.
Rudolph, the older one, who had bought himself a sword and armor and wanted to fight the Saracens - should he stay there? Was Max, not yet thirteen winters old, supposed to go alone?

What if the little boy stayed? But he got on so poorly with his father that even Richenza once slipped out that if it wasn't for Rudolph, the old master would have beaten the boy to death long ago. What would become of Max without the protection of his big brother?

For anyone who knew the brothers, it was unthinkable that they would separate. Of course, Rudolph could easily have managed on his own, but he was very attached to Max. Max himself was completely dependent on Rudolph, whom he literally adored. Whenever Radegunde's brothers got carried away, their mother always sighed, wishing her sons would get on as well with each other as Maximilian did.
And so it was a done deal. In the spring of 1147, the Halbig brothers left the master's house and went on a pilgrimage.

Richenza then tried to visit her sister more often than usual. The following winter, however, before there had been any news of the brothers, this came to an abrupt end: Radegunde's mother died. A severe fever took her within a week. She had already been pregnant again.

Maximiliane came from Frankfurt for her sister's funeral, the only time in all those years that she had left the city walls behind her. And when she saw the sad household - Radegunde's desperate, overworked father, the young, large group of children, and Radegunde herself, who at the age of eleven was anxiously wondering how she was going to cope - Maxi Halbig made her brother-in-law a generous offer.

Her own house was so empty and so spacious, she explained, the master had only had a second floor added a year ago and now her boys were gone. He, the brother-in-law, already had enough to do with his trade. Wouldn't he like to give the children to her, at least until they were a little older? She would be very happy about it - and the master would probably be too, as he has often complained about the silence.

Radegunde thought it was strange that the master had complained when he had always beaten Max up about it, but otherwise Aunt Maxi's offer came at just the right time for her. She was beside herself with happiness when her father accepted it. Less than three weeks after their mother's death, the numerous children moved to Frankfurt. And from then on, the master could no longer complain about emptiness and silence.

Radegunde wasn't quite sure whether they were getting on the old man's nerves or whether he was happy to see them. Occasionally, he trimmed one of her brothers, but then it was always more than appropriate. Otherwise, both Radegunde herself and her aunt made sure to bother the master as little as possible. However, before she could find out how he really felt about them, news arrived from Outremer, where the brothers had moved to.

In the summer of 1148, the news came to Frankfurt, which soon became a terrible certainty: The campaign of the German King Conrad had failed horribly. Even before they had reached the Holy Land, the Turks had attacked and almost completely wiped them out. There was practically no German army left.
And Rudolph and Max had gone with him.

The old master did not recover from this blow. On the day he learned that his sons were missing, he went to bed and never got up again. A good week later, they had to bury him. And at the master's funeral, the burden of responsibility really rested on Radegunde's shoulders, because Aunt Maxi had fallen seriously ill. The loss of her boys hit her just as hard as her husband.

However, she was a few years younger and there was still Radegunde and her siblings to look after, and that kept her aunt alive. After a few days she got up, after a few weeks she had her life in order. The wood-turning workshop was leased out, they were able to live off the income and they also had the house. Radegunde and her siblings may have lost their mother, and Maximiliane Halbig her husband and children - but they were able to hold and comfort each other.

Everyday life settled down well. The children loved their aunt, who brought them up with a calm, fair hand. Radegunde had now turned twelve and began to think about an outfit. And then the messenger came.

He came from Venice, from the other side of the Alps, and he brought news of Rudolph. Rudolph was alive. He was very badly injured, as the messenger said, and it was not certain how long he would live, but they were transporting him home. A litter in a merchant train would take him across the Alps, the good brothers of the Order of the Hospitallers would see to that. They were relying on the widow to cover the expenses, but she should be prepared for how badly injured her son was. A cripple would be brought back to her.

Radegunde hadn't realized that a light had gone out in Aunt Maxi's eyes on the day she had been told her boys were dead. Now it lit up and burned brighter than before. No, said the aunt in a very calm voice, she would bear all the expenses, and she didn't care how her son was brought back, as long as he was brought back to her. And then she began to organize.

Part of the main room was partitioned off with a wall and a bed was placed there. If Rudolph was no longer able to climb stairs, he would have his room there, from which he could also take part in life in the house during the day. She asked the apothecary about wound care and nursing, ordered a small supply of ointments and powders, and contacted the town physician and the herbalist outside the walls. She had a fresh mattress stuffed with straw and sewed a warm blanket. She prepared the house, yard and people for the arrival of a severely disabled person, and as she did so, she beamed a little more every day.
Rudolph came home in late fall.

Radegunde's eldest cousin had always been a feast for the eyes, a true god in the eyes of the little base: tall, with golden hair, green eyes and always a friendly smile. Rudolph was so good at talking about the saints, he was so wonderful on horseback and swung his sword with ease, even if he was sometimes a little clumsy. Rudolph was the epitome of a hero.
And what came home now was just a shadow.

They had been prepared for this. Aunt Maxi had taken the messenger's warnings to heart and had repeatedly pointed out to everyone, but really everyone, that Rudolph would not be the old man. But seeing it for yourself was something else. When you saw him like that, you wondered how he had survived the journey at all. Half of his left forearm was missing, his hand was simply gone. His breathing was raspy, his cheeks were unshaven and sunken. Red spots shone around his eyes, and his leg had healed crookedly, with an oozing wound. He was barely conscious when he arrived.

Aunt Maxi also paused for a moment, transfixed. But then she composed herself and got to work, calmly, carefully, as Radegunde knew her and relied on her. It had been like this ever since she had moved into her aunt's house. Looking back, she thought that Aunt Maxi behaved differently towards her nieces and nephews than she did towards her own children: Never had any of them been beaten as green and blue by the old master as Max once was. The aunt opened her mouth to her husband, which she had never done before. And since he was dead, she was in charge of the house, which suited her well. The servants appreciated her as a just mistress. She was not easily ruffled - and it was the same with Rudolph now.

He was given his camp behind the partition wall. The medic came, then the apothecary, then the herbalist, at a nicely coordinated distance. Aunt Maxi rolled up her sleeves and set about caring for her son, and Radegunde helped her to the best of her ability. Everyone in the house seemed to be trying to get Rudolph back on his feet, at least as far as possible.
On the second day after his return, he opened his eyes again for the first time and was responsive. His mother was with him, and Radegunde.

He had also been conscious briefly before, but they had used the short breaks in his delirium to feed him and give him something to drink so that he could regain his strength. Maximiliane Halbig had told her son at the first opportunity that he was at home and that he no longer needed to worry. Rudolph had simply closed his eyes in silence. But this time, on the second day, it was different. This time he was properly awake and able to speak.
‘Mother,’ he said, and after a brief, somewhat astonished glance, ‘Radegunde.’
‘We're here, my son,’ said the aunt lovingly, ‘you're home. Radegunde and her siblings are living with us now.’
‘Father?’
The aunt had to swallow.
‘Unfortunately, your father is no longer alive, Rudolph,’ she said honestly.
Rudolph closed his eyes again. But he opened them again just a moment later.
‘I understand,’ he said, ‘poor mother. Father is dead, and I ... and Max ...’

That was the word they had all been waiting for and dreading. Rudolph was back, but his little brother was not. Not a word had been said about him. Radegunde couldn't even imagine that Max would have left Rudolph voluntarily, and certainly not if he was seriously injured. So something terrible could only have happened.
Aunt Maxi obviously felt the same way. She put her hand on her son's arm.
‘You don't have to say anything now, Rudolph,’ she said hastily, ‘there's time until you feel better.’
But Rudolph did not agree.

‘No,’ he said, shaking his head, ‘you have a right ... I want you to know that it's my fault if Max doesn't come home. And I want you to know that I regret nothing more than the fact that I literally drove him, Katja and her children into the arms of the Seljuks.’
The aunt had gone completely silent. She didn't even seem to be breathing.
‘What do you mean?’ she asked choked.
And Rudolph began to tell the story.

On the train, it seemed, the brothers had soon made new friends: Gunild, an elderly woman whose husband died in Hungary; a family with a resolute mother called Magda; and finally Master Vogelmann from Mainz, his young wife and two children from a previous marriage.

Katharina Vogelmann had been heavily pregnant and had lost her child in Greece, which is how they had met. She was very young, much younger than the old master. The widowed Gunild had literally adopted the girl, her friend Magda had taken a fancy to the two children, and Max had been only too happy to entertain the two little ones with his antics. Basically, they had all taken Katharina and her children under their wing. Rudolph himself had seen the birdman's family as part of the small community that he had placed under his protection. However, the situation changed dramatically when the birdman died near Constantinople.

Katja Vogelmann, Rudolph said, was almost still a child - not much older than Max, and naïve and dreamy to boot. She was completely alone in the world, with nothing but the dubious protection of a clueless merchant, and had two children on her coat tails. God had placed this little family right at his feet, Rudolph said, he couldn't avoid it.

Both his mother and Radegunde knew that he had secretly toyed with the idea of dedicating his life to God and becoming one of those fighting monks that had been around for a few years. Katharina Vogelmann, however, turned his world upside down, and after a brief struggle he knew that her fate and his testimony to it were a sign from God. Because of her, he did not go with the army, but with the pilgrims under Otto von Freising. He would have had to wait until Jerusalem, as the birdman had ordered his wife to bring his heart to the Holy City when she died and she was considered untouchable until then. But as soon as the master's mortal remains had been buried in Jerusalem, he was determined to propose to the widow. Katharina Vogelmann needed protection, and he would give it to her. He had even already told Max. Of course, he hadn't spoken to her about it yet, but he was pretty sure she would have accepted.

But things turned out differently, terribly differently than planned. Still in Anatolia, not so far from the place where Konrad's men had been massacred, they too fell victim to the Turks. Rudolph quickly took Katharina and her children out of range, entrusted them to his brother and ordered him to hide with the girl and the two little ones until the attack had been repulsed. However, the attack was not repulsed. Rudolph finally managed to get away from the battlefield, badly injured, long after the battle had been lost. With his last ounce of strength, he searched for Max and his charges, and when he found them, he was sure he was going to die. He thought he could feel the Turks breathing down his neck and he ordered Max to take Katharina and her children and flee. He used the last of his authority to chase his brother away, to save him, as he believed, from death or slavery, for he, Rudolph, could no longer protect anyone. Catherine was crying, and Max was pale as a sheet, so pale and silent that Rudolph, hearing footsteps, thought they would never obey him. He literally begged them - and then Max gave in, took Katja and her children and fled.

The next thing Rudolph knew, Bishop Otto's men had found him and taken care of him. The Turks had never come to the place where the children had been hiding. If he, Rudolph, had given in and not scared the four of them away, they would be with him now. But as it was, they were completely on their own, without equipment, food or shelter, and had run off into the wild mountains of Anatolia.

‘I asked everyone I met about them,’ he said, ‘every monk in Attalia, everyone I saw. A few weeks later the French arrived, I had hoped for them, but they didn't know anything either. Before I was shipped to Italy, I asked one of the brothers to ask the merchants. No one had heard anything. I described them all in detail and a group like them, four children basically, should have stood out. But no one had heard of them.’
He took a deep breath and closed his eyes in agony.
‘Anatolia's mountains are full of Turks,’ he continued stifled, ‘and its Christian inhabitants are half Saracens themselves. They had no chance, mother. I chased them to their doom.’
He opened his eyes again and looked at his mother as tears welled up in his eyes.
‘I don't think,’ he said gruffly, ‘that Max will ever come home.’

Maximiliane Halbig didn't say much about it. She calmed her son down a little, looked after him and left the room as soon as he was asleep. But Radegunde found her outside in the courtyard a short time later, pale and with wet cheeks. Frightened, she sat down next to her aunt.
‘It doesn't have to be true!’ she said fiercely, ‘Rudolph is ill! Maybe Max is already on his way home!’
But the aunt shook her head.

‘No,’ she said quietly, ‘he's right. Something bad has happened, I know it. And I think ... oh Radegunde, I think all the time, if I had protected my boy better, here, in this house, if I hadn't had such a guilty conscience and therefore allowed his stepfather to treat him the way he did, if only I had been more like Rudolph - Max wouldn't have had to leave. He would have stayed here, in his parents' house, where a thirteen-year-old belongs.’
Radegunde, confused, was stuck on one word.
‘Stepdad?’ she repeated, puzzled.
Her aunt raised her head and looked at her. Then she wiped her cheeks, shook her head and smiled wryly.

‘Stepfather,’ she repeated, ‘that you don't know that ... Radegunde, Max was not the biological son of the old master, but the result of a ... I made a mistake when your mother got married. The master accepted him as his son, for my sake, but he never forgave Max for his existence. And I, I was too cowardly and too grateful to the old man for his name to save my child from his vengefulness. I allowed my husband to drive my son out of the house.’
She swallowed hard and added bitterly: ‘As punishment for that, I lost him forever.’

It was a bitter, sad taste that mingled with the joy of Rudolph's return. From that day on, Radegunde saw her aunt and her aunt's sons with different eyes. Aunt Maxi, so good and calm, seemed to her in retrospect to be tainted by a sad love story, and her behavior towards the old master was marked by silent acquiescence. Rudolph, who suffered so terribly from the loss of his little brother, became even nobler, even more saintly in her eyes because he had always protected the little one despite his questionable origins and treated him like his legitimate brother. And Max, the funny, reckless Max, seemed to her in retrospect to have worn his lightness only as a mask, as protection against his hard fate, knowing that he was worthless in the eyes of his stepfather. But of course she mainly thought of him that way because he was probably dead, and because everything in retrospect invited her to dream.

Winter passed, summer came, and then autumn came again. Rudolph recovered enough to get up from his bed and sit in an armchair during the day. He seemed to have resigned himself to his existence, lovingly looked after Radegunde's siblings and always had an open ear for all the worries and needs of the household. Radegunde sewed her trousseau and dreamed of a prince from the Orient - a Christian, of course - who would whisk her away to his fairytale castle.
And then came the news from the birdman in Mainz.

It was Radegunde herself who had overheard the news at the market. Breathless, her skirts flying, she chased home and shouted for Rudolph and her aunt in the doorway. And when they had both arrived and they had landed safely in the parlor, the information just gushed out of her, stunned, overwhelmed.
Katharina Vogelmann was back from the Holy Land.

The story had been told at the market: The little birdwoman had survived the journey reasonably unscathed, even though she had lost both her children, and had turned up at the house of guildmaster Wulfhart to claim her inheritance. Wulfhart let it be known everywhere that her hand was at his disposal, as her husband had died on the way to Outremer - and the birdman had been rich and famous.

‘They say that the Vogelmännin is perhaps the richest widow in town,’ said Radegunde breathlessly, ‘she's still young too, and there are no more children of the old man! They say the whole country will compete for her. But if you, Rudolph ...’
She broke off and fell silent at the look on her cousin's face.
Rudolph, like his mother, had listened stunned, breathless, overwhelmed by this astonishing news. But his face closed up at the last words.
It became quiet.
The aunt cleared her throat.
‘Any news from Max?’ she asked.
No, that was the sad part. Katharina Vogelmann, Radegunde had to report, had appeared alone and unaccompanied in front of the guild master's house. Not a word had been said about Max.
Silence fell again. Then the aunt took a deep breath.

‘So he didn't come back with her,’ she said, ‘well then. God's ways ... but at least she will know more about his whereabouts. You did say, Rudolph, that Katharina was with Max the last time you saw her?’
‘I had entrusted Katja and her children to Max,’ Rudolph replied, ‘but they said she had lost her children, and Max ... probably only she made it.’
‘We don't know,’ the aunt replied, ‘we'll ask her. I'll send a messenger to the girl, and then ... Rudolph, my dear. Shall we give the messenger something else?’
‘Yes, that's right, Rudolph,’ said Heinrich, who had been listening, ‘if she's so rich, the bird woman, don't you want to marry her? You wanted to anyway.’
‘That's right,’ said Radegunde, gathering her courage, ‘you wanted her. You should let her know you're here. Then she'll ...’
‘No!’ Rudolph interrupted them fiercely, ‘everyone, no! Stop it!’
They fell silent again and exchanged concerned glances. The aunt finally reached out her hand and placed it on Rudolph's mutilated arm.

‘Don't you want her anymore?’ she asked quietly, ‘or why don't you want to apply for her? I'm sure you'd have a good chance - if she knows you and wanted you back then. If she's like you described her to us...’
Rudolph didn't react for quite a while and no one said anything. But then he took a deep, heavy breath.
‘No,’ he said quietly, ‘I'm not going to apply. It just wouldn't be fair to Katja.’
He raised his head and looked at them in turn.

‘Katja Vogelmann has her head in the stars,’ he said gently, ‘you'd like her, she's sweet and friendly. But she's also very dreamy and sometimes blind to the world. If I came out to her, she'd feel obliged to take me in the end, because of old, unspoken things between us. Only - she needs a man other than me. She needs someone who can nurture and protect her, who can guide her, who won't leave her alone. And I'm no longer able to do any of those things.’
Aunt Maxi opened her mouth to protest, but Rudolph stood up.
‘No,’ he repeated, ‘that's my last word. I will not burden Katja Vogelmann with a cripple. And I ask you, mother, to wait with your messenger until she is married. She deserves better than me.’

There was little to add, although everyone, Radegunde, her aunt and even her little brother Heinrich tried to change Rudolph's mind over the next few days. Heinrich had tasted blood because of this legendary inheritance, Radegunde dreamed of the romantic story that had separated the lovers and could now bring them together again, and the aunt, yes, the aunt probably wished her remaining son all the luck she could. But Rudolph remained stubborn.

And so no messenger was sent, no offer was made. For a few weeks, Radegunde silently hoped for a miracle - and then she heard at the market that the bird woman had given her hand to a craftsman's son from Wiesbaden.

Rudolph said nothing, even though Radegunde wanted to believe that a little light had gone out in his eyes. She herself was heartbroken at the news, but her aunt didn't let on. As soon as she found out that the bird-woman was married, she sat down in the parlor with all the children and began to write a message to the girl. She could write, her aunt, which was a real miracle for Radegunde. She resolved to learn this art for the winter.

It took a few days to write the letter, then they sent a messenger and gave him the letter. The aunt said they would have to wait a good week for a reply. And if Katharina had moved away with her husband in the meantime and was no longer at the guild master's house in Mainz, then even longer. But they didn't have the young husband's address, because Radegunde had forgotten to ask for his name.

A good week, then, before she could receive news of her cousin's whereabouts, before perhaps the terrible confirmation of his end arrived. Radegunde didn't know whether to look forward to the answer or dread it.
And then everything happened again, everything was completely different - so incredibly different ...

It was the day after the messenger had ridden away. Radegunde was at the farm with her siblings, doing the last jobs before winter set in. She had opened the farm gate, the work was going well, and she herself was walking past the open gate when a voice came out of nowhere and struck her to the core.
‘Radegunde?’ she said incredulously, ‘you are Radegunde!’

She turned around. Opposite her stood a young man, a cap on his unruly, straw-blonde hair and a mischievous dimple in his cheek. Behind him, slightly offset, was a young woman with shiny, reddish hair, barely covered by a modest veil. Radegunde stared at them both in confusion.
‘You're Radegunde!’ the young man repeated, ‘It's me - Max!’

It was Max! It went through Radegunde like a bolt of lightning. Of course - the hair, the mischievousness, it was Max! Max, who had grown up after more than two years! She lost her composure. She burst into tears, stammered his name and threw her arms around his neck.

He sounded like Max, he felt like Max, he smelled like Max. Her cousin had actually come home, after all this time, after all the worrying and hoping, after the almost certain belief that he was lost - and now he was back, standing in front of her, holding her tight and stroking her back because she was sobbing from sheer shock and happiness. Max was back!
She caught herself a little and broke away from him again, wiping her face in embarrassment.
‘Oh heavens,’ she stuttered, ‘you don't even know ... you don't even know what happened!’
‘Did you come straight from Jerusalem?’ Heinrich wanted to know with wide eyes. Of course, all of Radegunde's siblings had left their work in the meantime and run to the farm gate.
Max grinned - his familiar, outrageous grin.
‘Well,’ he said, ‘at the moment I'm from Mainz, where I married the fabulously rich widow Vogelmann!’
‘What?’ Radegunde shrieked, and
‘Max!’ cried the young woman, and
‘That's not true!’ Heinrich was amazed.
‘Really, Max?’ Radegunde repeated, stunned, ‘you married the bird woman? The bird woman? Is that true?’
Max frowned. He didn't seem to have expected such a reaction.
‘Yes, I did,’ he said in surprise, grabbing the young woman's arm and pulling her next to him, ‘here, that's her - that's Katja. But how ... how do you know about her?’
‘Max,’ murmured the redhead, ‘I had applicants from all over the Rhineland - remember?’

Radegunde was not interested in these words. Instead, she marveled open-mouthed at this girl, this young woman of whom she had heard so much, and who now stood before her: Katharina Vogelmann, the widow of the old master goldsmith, well-traveled and much sought-after ...

Katja Vogelmann was of average height. Her face was even and nicely cut, her nose a little snub-like. Her skin was light, almost translucent, and her hair a shiny, coppery red. Her eyes were blue, like Max's, round and large, giving her the appearance of perpetual innocence. Her figure, however, was well-rounded and perfectly proportioned as far as could be seen under her clothes.
‘Really?’ Radegunde stuttered, ‘you're the birdwoman? The stone-rich birdwoman?’
‘Well,’ said Katharina with a rosy tinge in her cheeks, ‘whether I'm filthy rich...’

‘This is Radegunde, my base, and her siblings,’ Max quickly introduced, and Radegunde curtseyed automatically. Katharina returned the greeting. As she did so, Radegunde remembered her manners - and those who were sitting unsuspectingly in the house.
Heaven - Rudolph and Aunt Maxi!

‘Good God - how rude,’ she stammered as she turned deep red, ‘Heinrich, quick, go and get the aunt. And I ... come with me, leave the box, Max, the house servant can get it. Come on, I'll ... I'll take you into the house ...’
Max was obviously amused by her embarrassment.
‘I still know which way to go,’ he mocked.
But his wife gently rebuked him.
‘Shut up, Max,’ she said, ‘she's doing it just right. We're happy to follow you, Radegunde.’
And from that moment on, Radegunde deeply revered her legendary cousin by marriage.

But first there were more hurdles to overcome. At least Heinrich had fetched Aunt Maxi from the parlor, and so there was another scene of heartfelt welcome in the hallway, when the aunt lost her composure and, crying with happiness, pulled her youngest to her, praising the Lord time and time again. Katharina stood wide-eyed in the background, and Radegunde was proud on the one hand, but also terribly confused on the other.
And then Max took Katharina's hand, led her in front of his mother and introduced her.

Aunt Maxi's reaction was not quite as reverent as Radegunde's had been. She reacted rather cautiously, unsure what to do with this daughter-in-law that the younger son had brought her, when she had intended her for the elder. And this was the moment when Heinrich blurted out that they had thought Rudolph would marry the bird-woman.
‘Rudolph?’ Max asked, confused, ‘why Rudolph...?’

Rudolph, inside the parlor, must have heard them long ago. Perhaps it had taken him so long to get to his feet, perhaps the shock had robbed him of all strength at first, perhaps he had waited for someone to come to him. But now, when his name had been called, he stepped out of the room, slowly, carefully. He stopped in the doorway, looked at his brother, at his brother's bride and said: ‘Max. And - Katharina.’

It was deathly quiet. Radegunde suddenly realized that both Max and his wife must have believed that Rudolph had died in Anatolia. That was why they had come to tell their aunt about their eldest's death - without realizing that Rudolph had long since returned home. They both stood stock-still, Max had his mouth open, his eyes wide with shock, and Katharina was as pale as the wall, as if she were seeing a ghost.
‘Yes,’ said the aunt, ‘Rudolph has come home too.’

And that broke Max's spell. He let out a strange sound, half moan, half sob, and flew across the room, right around his brother's neck. Rudolph almost staggered under the onslaught, dropped his stick with a clatter and finally wrapped his arms around Max.
‘Mäxchen,’ he whispered hoarsely, ‘Mäxchen, my little one.’
Max was crying. They heard him sobbing chokedly, gasping for breath, they saw him trembling, his head pressed against Rudolph's shoulder, incredulous, stunned, overwhelmed.
And Katharina fainted.

The aunt, the clever, all-seeing aunt, had long since grabbed her daughter-in-law's arm. Now she called Max's name in a sharp voice. Katharina had slumped to the floor, her face as white as ashes, her eyes open and blind. Max, confused, stirred, lifted his head - and was then at his wife in one movement. He carefully pulled her close.
‘Katja?’ he asked, ‘Katja!’
‘Katharina?’ said Rudolph, approaching with a limp, ‘is she ill?’
‘Is she dying?’ whispered one of the children.

‘No, she doesn't,’ said the aunt energetically, ‘she just needs a little rest. Break it up, rascals, let her breathe. Max, we'd better put her down. Radegunde and Liesbet, clear your bed, you can sleep with me. Katharina and Max need a place to sleep.’

Calmly, with prudence and energy, the aunt ensured order and put an end to this confusion, where both brothers had had to learn that the other, believed dead, was still alive, and that the bride of one had become the bride of the other. She sent Rudolph back into the parlor, ordered Max to carry his wife into the chamber and shooed the little ones away. Radegunde brought her some essence for Katharina's temples, then she too had to leave the room, where the girl lay on her bed, Max perched on the edge of the bed with a lost, confused look in his eyes, and where Aunt Maxi remained.

Radegunde went into the parlor, to Rudolph and her siblings, who bombarded her with questions. Out of necessity, she answered what she could and didn't get a chance to speak to Rudolph, who sat in his corner shaking his head in bewilderment. When her aunt came down shortly afterwards, things calmed down a little, but that was all.
‘He's back, Mother,’ Rudolph said, clutching her hand, ‘Mäxchen is back. God is good.’
‘Yes,’ said the aunt, ‘that's him. We must never forget that.’
Rudolph looked at her, nodded - and not a word was said about Katharina, the bride.

Nothing changed when Max came to them. He had grown taller, broader in the small of his back and in his shoulders, but he was still the same Max, even if he now looked a little helpless. He sat down next to Rudolph, staring at him as if a pure miracle had happened, and Rudolph, after a moment, looked the same. He reached out his healthy hand, ran it through Max's hair and left it on the back of his neck.
‘Tell me what happened,’ he said harshly.
Max, with tears in his eyes, shook his head.

‘No,’ he replied, ‘you first. What I have to say will take days, and I ... Rudolph, I thought you were dying. I really thought ... I would never have left if I had given you another chance. I would never have let you down, I would never have betrayed you! You have to believe me!’
Now Rudolph also had tears in his eyes.
‘Oh Mäxchen,’ he said gently, ‘I know. I thought I was going to die, too.’

They all listened quietly while Rudolph briefly recounted his experiences. Max had tears streaming down his face, but he smiled, and he still looked at Rudolph with that look in his eyes that Radegunde knew from him - admiring, loving, mixed with a little disbelief. Finally he began to tell a wild story of soldiers, Turks and knights, of foreign countries and cities, of princes, dukes and kings.

With great difficulty, he managed the feat of not even mentioning his wife's name, although she must have been by his side the whole time. And Rudolph didn't even ask about her, not even when Max spoke of their son's death.
Katharina only came back downstairs much later.
To say that the situation over the next few days was tense would have been a complete understatement. Max, Rudolph and Katja were simply overwhelmed by the situation. Even Radegunde could see that.

Perhaps it would have been easier if the relationship between the brothers had not been so close before. Perhaps they could have dealt with it better if there had already been a certain rivalry between them. But the fact was that Max had always idolized Rudolph, that Rudolph had protected and loved the little boy, and that, apart from the odd harmless banter, there had never been a bad word spoken between them. They were simply too different to be jealous of each other. So far, the roles had been clearly divided, there had never been anything that they could both consider their property and fight over at the same time.
And now there was Katharina.

Max couldn't come to terms with it at all. He had firmly believed that Rudolph was dead and had entrusted his bride to him with his last words. For most of the journey, he had even treated her like a sister. Why he had ended up taking her as his wife - well, that was open to speculation. Her aunt, who was keeping a close eye on her newfound son, told Radegunde that she thought Max had simply fallen in love. But that meant that, although he couldn't have known it, he had fallen in love with his brother's bride, who was still alive, and snatched her from under his nose. And Max simply couldn't deal with that.

Rudolph, on the other hand, was confused, a little hurt and relieved that Max and Katja were alive. It seemed to Radegunde that the latter clearly outweighed the former. Of course, it must have seemed strange to him to find his bride in her little brother's bed - but Max was alive after he, Rudolph, had thought he had chased the little one to his death, and that was much more important. Rudolph, it seemed to Radegunde, would have forgiven Max anything, including this. As far as his relationship with Katharina was concerned, it was a little more difficult. Although he was glad that she was alive, he seemed uncomfortable in her presence, as if he didn't know exactly how he should behave towards her. Katharina's uncertainty in the first few days didn't help to clarify things.

Katja was the one who knew Radegunde the worst, or in other words, didn't know her at all and therefore couldn't assess her. But Rudolph had been right about one thing in his description: she was kind and sweet, and not the least bit malicious. She was visibly uncomfortable, visibly upset to suddenly be standing between the brothers, and she felt left alone. That was quite understandable, because she didn't know anyone apart from Max and Rudolph, and Rudolph was reserved towards her, whereas Max simply ignored her.

For a few days, Radegunde observed her younger cousin's behavior with amazement. From one moment to the next, Max seemed to have reverted to his old role: the bastard brother of the beautiful Rudolph, who had nonsense on his mind and was always in trouble. If the old master had still been alive, Radegunde would not have been surprised if Max had been chased around the yard again or locked up in the cellar. But above all, he didn't behave as if he were married. He no longer saw his wife, practically never spoke to her, and at night they obviously lay next to each other in silence. Max concentrated all his energy on the brother he had found again - and since he couldn't reconcile the fact that he had married his bride with this, he ignored her as if she wasn't even there.

Katja felt sorry for Radegunde after just one day. She watched her new base trying to make the best of the situation, pausing in uncertainty as her husband shamefully let her down, and she thought inwardly what a shameful welcome they had given the bird woman. Apparently her aunt felt the same way. Without any need for consultation, both Radegunde and her aunt took Katharina by the hand, were friendly, talked to her and made an effort to get to know her better. Katja was visibly very grateful for their efforts. She gained a little more confidence and ended up having a long conversation with Rudolph without Max being in the same room. Because when the two brothers were in a room together, Katja was simply non-existent.

Radegunde was present during this conversation. At first it was awkward, as it had been all the days before, but then it gathered momentum, as if they were forgetting Max and falling back into their old roles. Katja asked, Rudolph answered. Rudolph began to ramble on - about faith and the Promised Land - and Katja listened, wide-eyed. When she left, she looked very thoughtful, as if this conversation had answered an important question, even if Radegunde didn't understand what it was. Rudolph seemed more relaxed afterwards, as if his position had been clarified, and Katja finally shed her insecurity in the days that followed and determined her place for herself.

Whatever had happened, for whatever reason this situation had come about, she was Max's wife and no amount of violence in the world could change that. She saw it, Rudolph saw it, the whole house saw it.
Only Max, who continued to act as if this fact did not exist.

Katharina's insecurity gradually turned to anger. Increasingly, her indignation at being treated in this way by her husband seemed to grow, even though she had always acted to the best of her knowledge and conscience. Radegunde and her aunt watched her anger swell. She became more biting, she became more venomous, she let Max feel her resentment, although he tried not to notice. And then, one day at dinner, she exploded.
It had only been a matter of time, that was clear. Max ignored her once too often and Katja stood up, thundered her hands on the table and hissed at him: ‘We need to talk!’

No one dared to interfere in this marital dispute. Max tried to wriggle out again, but Katja obviously had no intention of leaving him a loophole. She literally grabbed him by the scruff of the neck and dragged him upstairs to the bedroom. There the door was shut with a bang, and everyone was actually expecting wild shouting and screaming.
Nothing of the sort happened.

At first there was silence. Then it sounded as if something was falling to the floor, and then again, and then there was a thump. Shortly afterwards, there were heavy noises from above, which Radegunde had occasionally heard from her parents' bed when her mother was still alive.
Katja gasped. Max groaned.

Radegunde was confused. What had happened to the argument? She glanced uncertainly at Rudolph, who had suddenly turned bright red, and then at her aunt, who was biting her lips as if suppressing a grin. The noises were getting louder and louder, more and more violent.
‘But what are they doing?’ wondered six-year-old Hänschen with wide eyes.
‘Is he going to kill her?’ asked Liesbet anxiously.
‘Or she him?’ Heinrich joked.
‘Hardly,’ grumbled Rudolph, and his aunt added tensely: ‘Don't worry, children. Max and Katja - hm - are just tidying up the room a bit.’
‘And that's why they're moaning like that?’ Hänschen doubted.
‘They're probably just moving the bed,’ said the aunt chokingly, ‘you know how hard that is.’
‘The bed?’ Hänschen seemed anything but convinced - and Radegunde suddenly realized what was happening up there.

Uh-oh. She didn't know for sure what happened between husband and wife once they'd tied the knot, but it was probably close to it up there. It was what her parents used to do under the covers. It was what Max and Katja had been expected to do at night, and what had never happened - until now. Now they seemed to be making up for lost time with all their vigor. Radegunde felt the blood rush to her head. Rudolph was just as glowing as she was, and Aunt Maxi's cheeks were also rosy, although that was probably due to suppressed laughter rather than shame.
And then, finally, it became quiet.
‘Are they finished now?’ asked Liesbet.
‘I hope so,’ muttered Rudolph.
‘I think so, dear,’ said her aunt, ‘eat up, children. Max and Katja will be back for dessert.’
‘Sure?’ said Rudolph with gentle mockery, but without malice.
‘I hope so,’ his mother replied.
And after a moment, she added uncertainly: ‘But maybe I'll go and see what's going on.’
She took the stairs and knocked on the door at the top.
‘Max?’ she called out.
It was quiet for a moment, then there was a heavy rustling and Max's breathless voice rang out.
‘Yes? Mother?’

If Radegunde had had any doubts about what had just happened, this conversation would have dispelled them. The aunt pointed out the dessert and that they were expected, and both Max and Katja answered - hastily, embarrassed, guilty. And when they finally came back downstairs - they had never had to wait so long for dessert - they were both beaming and holding hands.
‘Well,’ said her aunt so quietly that only Radegunde could hear, ‘that was an unusual way of pronouncing it.’
Radegunde was just about to ask when her aunt added: ‘But if it works ... she knows how to take it. That's good, that's good. Max needs a woman like her.’
And Radegunde preferred not to say anything, especially as she suddenly wasn't sure whether she should have heard the words at all.
